>>> <snip>
>>> Comparison with WWW is not fair. =C2=A0=
There is a single shared semantic

 brains (so far) are way better

ftware code.

>>>
>>> think about what you say here: that there =
is a "shared semantic"
>>> understanding. and where does this understanding=
 exist? only (and
>>> solely) in the head of humans?

One could argue =
there are at least two levels:
1) Technically, a common meaning of HTML tag=
s, interpreted uniformly
(well, almost) across browsers
2) A shared meaning=
 conveyed by the language and visual symbols and
eventually emerging, yes, =
in human heads.  Eventually, because it
depends on the context, culture, et=
c.

There is an analogy with 1) uniform POST semantics at the network
level=
 and 2) application meaning from the pov of application.

>>> after careful=
 review, i claim you will find that there *are*
>>> real-world markers, ind=
icators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
>>> real world; ones that ar=
e recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
>>> activated by humans. Curre=
ntly, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
>>> are rendered by common Web =
browsers via the messages sent by servers
>>> in the most ubiquitous human-=
centered hypermedia format of the day;
>>> HTML.
>>>
>>> "Semantic meaning"=
 is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
>>> property is "created=
" by humans when they observe the visual
>>> "landscape" rendered by =C2=A0=
Web browsers.

Not necessarily an emergent property only. The meaning can b=
e formally
defined by humans (by logic, common vocabularies, knowledge
repr=
esentation, etc) and encoded in the software. The encoded semantic
essentia=
lly constitutes  the shared understanding between the client
and the server=
.

>>>
>>> Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can=

>>> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-time
>>>=
 interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers?
>>

An=
ybody can create a client, which will read the same HTML tags on a
web page=
, but it will hardly be expected these days to have full human
reasoning ca=
pabilities.

>> Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven'=
t seen a
>> client implementation which demonstrates automated capabilities=
 which
>> come 'close' to that of a human, we're basically talking about th=
e
>> web's version of a Turing Test.
>>

Indeed.

>> Most of the evidence s=
o far suggests this is the case, although I am
>> not an AI expert.
>>

Or
>>> is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
=
>>> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>>> "afford=
ances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>>>
>>> It is my assertion that t=
he latter is the case. I also contend that
>>> making the assumption that t=
his is possible is a key step in advancing
>>> the art and theory of distri=
buted hypermedia.
>>>

Well, if regarding hypermedia as one of the instance=
s of knowledge
representation, this is certainly within the research scope =
of AI /
machine learning.

>>
>> I think it's an interesting research topic=
 but the complexity of
>> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's=
 inevitable that only

is way (unless you

ry distributed!).
>> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve you=
r application in

dermining the

allenge
